Himmelsbach | Give us more Cards-Hoosiers

Neighbors should be annual rivals.

Himmelsbach | Give us more Cards-Hoosiers

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 1:42 a.m. EST December 10, 2014

Louisville guard Chris Jones (3) drives around Indiana guard Nick Zeisloft (2) in the first half of an NCAA college basketball game at Madison Square Garden in New York, Tuesday, Dec. 9, 2014. (AP Photo/Kathy Willens)(Photo: AP)

10 CONNECT 8 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

NEW YORK – The University of Louisville and Indiana University are separated by about 100 miles yet inextricably linked by their love of basketball. The Cardinals and the Hoosiers are two of the more storied programs in the college game, and the passion of their respective fan bases is unquestioned.

And so in one sense it was fantastic to see them facing each other at Madison Square Garden at the Jimmy V Classic on Tuesday night. And in another sense, it was a shame that it has taken this long for it to happen, and that they had to travel all the way to New York to make it happen.

Louisville vs. Indiana is a logical rivalry, just as Louisville vs. Kentucky and Indiana vs. Kentucky are, and yet Cards vs. Cats is the only one of those match-ups that is still taking place each year. And that's too bad.

"If they keep [UofL/IU] going," Cardinals forward Wayne Blackshear said, "it'd be a great rivalry."

MORE: What we learned in U of L/Indiana

MORE: Instant Analysis from U of L-IU in New York

The atmosphere at Madison Square Garden during U of L's 94-74 win was wonderful, because the atmosphere at Madison Square Garden is almost always wonderful. And there was buzz even even though one entire side of the second level was empty.

Louisville coach Rick Pitino: Indiana win "a lot of fun"

If this game came home, clearly, there would not be empty seats, much less empty sections. It would be good for Kentuckiana and it would be good for the sport. On Tuesday night, Cardinals coach Rick Pitino was asked whether he would like to see this game become a more regular occurrence.

"What I suggested to [Indiana coach Tom Crean] was we go to Lucas Oil Stadium [in Indianapolis] for two years and we try to break the attendance record, you know, we try to get 80,000," Pitino said. "Each team gets 40,000 [tickets] and whoever can't sell the 40 returns them. I'm pretty sure we can bring 40; I'm pretty sure they can bring 40."

And that would be pretty great. But the reality is that probably is not going to happen anytime soon. Schedules fill up quickly, and IU has been reluctant to play these games at neutral sites, and beyond Pitino's line, there was been no indication that this idea will turn into something more.

In 2012, the UK/IU series came to an end after the two sides couldn't agree on a location. Indiana wanted a home-and-home series, and UK wanted the games to be played at neutral sites--including Lucas Oil Stadium. Wildcats coach John Calipari reportedly had no interest in returning to Bloomington--where his team had lost during its national title season. Crean ostensibly had no interest in going to a cavernous arena that would probably be invaded by Big Blue Nation.

And so there is little reason to believe IU would be thrilled about Pitino's suggestion, either, although the fan bases of U of L and IU are a bit more of a fair fight numbers-wise.

Before this game, the Cardinals and Hoosiers last faced each other in 2003, with U of L taking a 95-76 victory at Freedom Hall. That came one year after Indiana won in Bloomington. Prior to that, the teams had not met since 1993. In all, they have played a total of just 17 games against each other. That's not enough.

Ideally, U of L, IU and UK would have a kind of round-robin setup, where the three rotate and play one another on varying home courts. Yes, a huge football stadium would be a huge moneymaker, but home games are what make college basketball magical, even though Pitino made it clear that is not his preferred option here.

    Tuesday's game was not only fun because of the storied histories of these programs; it was fun because of its flow. It was a frenetic, fast-paced and mostly well-played basketball game. There were big dunks, big blocks, big stars and big runs.

    MORE: Game Rewind | U of L outlasts IU at MSG

    When IU surged back from a 13-point deficit to take a 50-46 lead in the second half, the building was alive. And when U of L, unfazed and unbothered, punched right back with a 37-20 surge to regain control, the drama rose. It was a good basketball game on a good night, and it would be great for both of these programs if it turned into something more regular.

    Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach​
